discourse_list.title: Can we justify the existential risk posed by PSM-USDC?

content.content: I’ve been concerned about the amount of DAI generated from USDC since long before becoming a delegate. Now that we’ve reached an ATH of 80% of DAI (and rising) being backed by centralized stable assets, we simply won’t be doing our jobs unless we directly confront the reality of the risks. Circle has the power to blacklist/freeze the USDC in the PSM without notice. This would indefinitely freeze the collateral backing 80% of DAI in existence, causing an existential crisis for the entire DAO. This is an untenable risk. We simply cannot leave the fate of the DAO in the hands of Circle or any other 3rd party. We must do everything that we can to avert existential threats like this. In DeFi and crypto in general, if it can happen we must assume that it will happen. We have no idea what the future will bring, or how regulators will view the stablecoin scene in the near future. If we keep our heads buried in the sand on this and only focus on what is likely then we will simply not be doing our jobs. We need to focus on what is possible and then determine our risk tolerance based on that. This cannot wait. If we do not think adversarially now, then we are simply not doing everything we can to protect MakerDAO. I would like to use this thread to kick-start the following, in this order:   Request that CUs use this as a safe space to offer some realistic modeling & scenarios (PE, legal, any other relevant takes) regarding exactly what would happen if all USDC in the PSM got blacklisted/frozen. Let’s get real. Don’t sugar coat it. Think adversarially. Tell us exactly how this would go, where the unknowns lie, and what state DAI could find itself in as a result.   Ask staunch PSM supporters to justify the risk that the scenarios presented in Step 1 become reality. “That is so unlikely to happen” is not allowed here. This could happen so we need to justify the decision to even allow it to exist as a possibility. If the bear market shaves even more value off ETH, we could even see 85-90% DAI via PSM. Explain to us why you believe that placing the fate of the DAO in the hands of a highly-regulated 3rd party is worth the incredible risk, and why reducing or eliminating the PSM is an existentially bad idea despite the outlined potential scenarios.   As a DAO, decide whether or not the reasons to keep the PSM in its current state (or at all) are worth the risks & justifications that have been established. Discuss alternatives & trade-offs. Then, finally, allow MKR holders themselves to determine whether the peg stability that has been achieved is worth the identified existential risk presented by USDC’s centralization.   If the DAO is going to continue to exist at the will of Circle/USDC, then we need to justify it. If we can’t justify it, then we need to change it.  I’m hopeful that this exercise will ultimately lead to a drastic reduction or even eventual elimination of the PSM, and I also hope that by doing this thoughtfully, we can recognize which trade-offs are ultimately worth it and which are not. I welcome any & all input on the process I’ve suggested.

The best thing to do for the time being would be to create psm entry and exit fees, which would make DAI more expensive in the market, incentivizing vault creators with other assets to issue DAI and sell it on the open market. It would also give DAI more value and generate revenue to the protocol, which could go to buy a decentralized asset exchange, like Ethereum.

The solution to the large PSMs is to increase diverse loan demand to match DAI demand.  This is everything that is being worked on.  We are close to having treasuries and a portion of the PSMs will be diversified there very soon.  Just have to be a little patient.  USDC is the most liquid on chain asset that allows MKR to have excess demand for DAI without affecting the dollar peg.  It’s just a representation of demand that can in the future be managed once there are enough avenues to find nonstablecoin collateral for the DAI (such as treasuries).  Again, this is what is worked on every day.  There will always be counterparty risk.  The key is to diversify and manage this risk. But on the topic of circle freezing assets, we do need to recognize that circle would take a huge reputational hit if it were to do this.  If we can trust that circle is fully backed and can repay the usdc is out there, we should be ok.  Of course it’s always a big if to trust anyone, but usdc is at least the most trusted centralized stablecoin and it’s failure to repay its obligation would likely signify a huge market event for all of crypto.  This would certainly affect MKR whether or not MKR was exposed to USDC.  All of crypto is exposed to USDC.

Hey Chris, thanks for putting this together. I just want to point out some corrections on the numbers mentioned in the problem description.     ChrisBlec:  Now that we’ve reached an ATH of 80% of DAI (and rising) being backed by centralized stable assets   Dai generated from collateral is not the same as Dai collateralization. All Dai in circulation are backed by all collateral in the system “at the same time,” no matter which collateral each Dai was minted from, because, for example,  1 Dai minted from PSM-USDC is fully fungible with 1 Dai minted from ETH-A. A great way to understand the difference between these two metrics is: Dai minted from collateral measures the demand of each type of Dai collateralization (source of minted Dai), and Dai collateralization measures the composition of all assets backing all Dai. Edit:  Not 100% accurate, my bad, corrected here  image - 2022-06-29T110619.6151378×435 83.4 KB  According to daistats.com, PSM-USDC represents 36.9% of all collateral value in the system. If we add PSM-USDP and USDC-A, the number will go to 44.9%.     ChrisBlec:  Circle has the power to blacklist/freeze the USDC in the PSM without notice. This would indefinitely freeze the collateral backing 80% of DAI in existence   If all USDC in the system suddenly goes to zero or is blacklisted, to calculate the amount of potential unbacked Dai we can say that:   Math   There’s 6.7 billion Dai in circulation.   There’s 3.2 billion USDC in PSM-USDC + 227 million in USDC-A = ~3.4 billion USDC   There’s $8.7 billion worth of collateral in the system.   If $3.4 billion worth of collateral (3.4 billion USDC) is removed, the system will lose $3.4 billion of collateral: $8.7 billion - $3.4 billion = $5.3 billion   The result is $5.3 billion backing 6.7 billion Dai (collateralization ratio of ~79%)   Well, this is just simple math, I’m not taking into account other potential risks of deleting the PSM reserves, which would be bad for Dai peg’s strenght.   Not accurate, my bad, corrected here And that’s an important part of why the PSM reserves and their quality are important for Dai to be resilient. The PSM is a permissionless liquidity tool for Dai. During stress situations, just as the last one the crypto market had in May, the $1 Dai peg would be as strong as the ability to redeem 1 Dai for $1. If we do not give this the importance it requires, Dai holders could lose their savings before we find the solution to PSM-USDC PSM-USDC is a good, high-quality collateral that supports the success of Dai. We have other solutions to build this permissionless liquidity, like G-UNI vaults, but PSM is the most successful liquidity tool Maker has ever had. In my opinion, all PSM-USDC being blacklisted is a very unlikely situation and that is an important fact to keep in mind when considering risks. And, well, I am not a financial/risks expert in the mechanism of Maker and Dai, I just wanted to point out my vision with the information that I have. I’m sure Strategic Finance, Real World Finance or Risk team could add more PSM factors with greater importance for the success of Dai and Maker systems.

If all USDC in the system suddenly goes to zero or is blacklisted, to calculate the amount of potential unbacked Dai we can say that:  There’s 6.7 billion Dai in circulation. There’s 3.2 billion USDC in PSM-USDC + 227 million in USDC-A = ~3.4 billion USDC There’s $8.7 billion worth of collateral in the system. If $3.4 billion worth of collateral (3.4 billion USDC) is removed, the system will lose $3.4 billion of collateral: $8.7 billion - $3.4 billion = $5.3 billion The result is $5.3 billion backing 6.7 billion Dai (collateralization ratio of ~79%)   It doesn’t work this way. If a user deposits $100B of BTC and draws 1 DAI from it, we can’t use his $99.999999999B of BTC to collateralize other vaults that have failed. Realistically, if 80% of DAI loses its backing, every vault owner will pay pay back their loans (buying super cheap DAI off of the market if needed) and withdraw their collateral. Then, 0% of DAI will be backed & the whole project fails.

I think we need to differentiate between a couple types of censorship risk:  Circle (and/or other issuers) freeze all centralized stablecoins in the PSM(s) Circle (and/or other issuers) shift to a whitelist model for permitting transfers - basically freeze all centralized stablecoins throughout defi Circle (and/or other issuers) dishonor centralized stablecoin liabilities entirely  I believe all of these potential risk factors are fairly remote, and we would be highly likely to have weeks/months of advanced notice before assets are suddenly censored. But still worth considering the potential impacts. (1) would cause significant liquidity issues for DAI - users could no longer immediately redeem DAI for USDC/centralized stablecoins at 1:1 parity. But other exchange venues like Curve and Uniswap would still support DAI liquidity. And the backing of issued DAI is fundamentally still intact, just illiquid - we could assume that users would count locked up USDC at some discounted value based on expected time to resolve the legal issues and risk of (3) eventually happening. (2) would be more disruptive. First, pooled liquidity markets like Compound and Aave would basically get nuked into oblivion as liquidations of USDC/centralized stablecoin debt or collateral would no longer be possible. The majority of DAI liquidity (in PSMs and stablecoin swap pairs) would also become inaccessible, which would cause significant instability. However, DAI collateralization would still be fundamentally intact. Funds held in stablecoin LP vaults would also still be transferable, so Maker could potentially raise interest rates on or liquidate these positions if DAI began to trade below peg to help contract supply. I think this sort of govt action happening on short notice would be completely untenable from a public policy perspective - willfully causing significant collateral damage on US retail investors for no fault of their own. (3) would be a full on rug. To get here we’d have to assume that the rule of law has completely collapsed in the US, and then ammunition and canned food would be the only currency with any real value. For the near future I don’t think it makes much sense to try to optimize protocol design for this risk because potential solutions would kill DAI utility without significantly increasing likelihood of survival. As far as solutions:  Creating trustless wrappers around centralized stablecoin balances held in PSMs could reduce liquidity risks arising under cases including (1) and (2) Finishing development of VOX (target price adjustment module, similar to RAI) would be helpful as a backup plan in case Maker needs to rapidly offboard centralized stablecoins, although recent history of RAI shows this is does not work very well (rates are currently -25% APR and market price remains far above target price) Win the public policy debate around censorship resistance; I think all parts of the political spectrum are gaining increasing appreciation of censorship resistance (eg. the response to Canada trucker protest really concerned me even tho I don’t really align politically with the protesters) and imo our best bet is gain broad public support where targeting DAI in furtherance of government financial control is untenable  So in summary: Yes I believe the risks posed by PSMs and other centralized asset exposures are justified

What appealed to me was the fact that Maker was trying to build an asset that would be crypto native and provide a medium of exchange that was largely uncensorable and an alternative asset for crypto natives. What Maker has instead turned into is pretty much an organization that is increasingly centralized and struggling to demonstrate its value proposition versus USDC, which is subject to regulatory capture and has severe centralization concerns. Every time people mention the issues associated with USDC and the blacklist risk, we hear “well they’d never do that, it would kill their business, etc., etc.” I second your call for an in-depth analysis and discussion about the risks associated with having nearly 50% of DAI backed by USDC, and the impact to the protocol if this were to be blacklisted due to regulators’ discomfort with DAI’s permissionless nature. As a reminder, I called out these risks three years ago in this post. I made the following points:   The Maker system becomes less resilient against attack: Currently, despite the fact that there is no Foundation, every step Maker takes to become tied to real-world assets, not reduce reliance on USDC, it’s easier to attack.   KYC requirements are hugely unpopular in some crypto circles:: A major selling point for DAI is permissionless nature. I don’t see that surviving with the current Maker path.   The final thing I’ll say is this (quoting from my original article): The whole Open Finance ecosystem falls apart if Dai can be seized/blocked from an application because central actors say that the currency is compromised, or they don’t like that CDPs were opened without KYC requirements, etc. I’d love to hear from Maker about what it thinks about this threat, and how it plans to mitigate these risks, and even if it thinks they are not credible (and why).

First a caveat: I’ve only skimmed this thread, apologies if I’m repeating others. Second a clear explanation of my view of an ‘ideal’ state in terms of the PSM:  PSM USDC/others makes up 5-10% of total DAI supply. A tested and 24-hour viable method to wind down PSMs in an emergency.  Third, why we need the PSM, and a depressing comment on this:     ChrisBlec:  DAI worked before the PSM existed.   TL;DR, no it didn’t. I’m defining working as:  Providing a stablecoin that stays within 0.5% of its peg, and frankly this is generous, as many have said that this is far too volatile for institutional use of a stablecoin.  Realistically, most users do not care about decentralization primarily when evaluating stablecoins. Order of wants for stablecoins is essentially:  Extremely tight peg stability Trust in long-term safety of the underlying systems and backing. Decentralization  Bluntly, DAI does not work without the PSM because the incentive for stabilization is (in the absence of a PSM) expressed in the price of the DAI token. In order for the incentive to be meaningful, DAI is already not working by the above definition. To those that might dispute the above, we have empirical evidence that the incentive isn’t strong enough within 0.5% from the market price of DAI after Black Thursday.  We had rates at 0%. DAI was trading above peg, I forget the magnitude and I don’t want to go look it up, but at times it was significant, on the order of 1-2 cents semi-regularly.  Again, put bluntly, the incentive provided by deviation in the DAI price is not sufficient to overcome the risk of leverage on volatile collateral in a bear market, or the cost of hedging that volatility. Thus, PSM. Which is an excellent and useful innovation to ensure short-term stability for DAI. The problem develops from the following: Fundamentally, there is not enough demand for credit using decentralized collateral (specifically ETH) to support the DAI supply beyond a certain point. I will grant that theoretically we could take a larger market share from Aave and Compound, but there is still a hard limit to scaling from this approach that is a combination of:  Demand for credit using decentralized collateral from owners of decentralized collateral. The price of decentralized collateral.  This results in what would ideally be a short-term only mechanism in the PSM becoming a long-term mechanism, as we’ve seen for the past few years. However, the above isn’t news to anyone. It has been the driver of all major supply-scaling initiatives within Maker for maybe 2 years, the major two being:  Collateral Onboarding Real World Assets  The idea behind #1 was that other decentralized assets could and would develop which may reach a substantial fraction of ETH’s market-cap, and therefore support lots of demand for credit. In practice this hasn’t happened (and may never happen.) The idea behind #2 was that we know there is sufficient demand for credit in the legacy financial system for existing assets. If we can solve the complicated problem of using said assets as collateral safely, then we can scale DAI. So, with that extremely abbreviated history of why we’re in the place we’re in. We come to the possibility of alternatives. Again, simply put, there are no good alternatives. The closest we could come are probably:  Buying a significant amount of other decentralized fully-collaterallized stablecoins (like all of them.) Specifically LUSD and FEI. This has downsides. Having the protocol take a massive bet on ETH (similar to FEI) and directly mint DAI to purchase ETH and pray that number go up. This also has downsides.  With 100% seriousness, if you can convince me that an alternative exists that can realistically provide credibly decentralized backing for say 500M DAI with less existential risk (as evaluated by a risk expert) than USDC in the PSM, I would love to hear it, and I will help you campaign/persuade others to implement it. Then we just need 7 equally good and safe ideas for decentralized backing to reduce the PSM size to survivable numbers. Absent that the choice is between:  Real World Assets Lots of PSM DAI Making DAI even less competitive when compared to centralized stablecoins.   This was long. Apologies. My views, not GovAlpha’s, etc.

They are not the same, CBDC would have different distribution models which are more favorable due to the disintermediation of multiple layers. USDC has more intermediaries and therefore additional risks like counterparty, default and credit risk  CBDC would be a central bank’s liability, so that eliminates default and credit risk. Hey @davoice321.     davoice321:  governments around the world seeking greater control and visibility into digital assets, and clearly being against “unhosted” wallets and financial activities without intermediaries   I do not share this particular view of the world, it’s just too much of a generalization. Just wanted to leave that on the record. To your points / questions:     davoice321:  Can you quantify what “remote” means? Is it a 1% chance, .05%? How would you define it? Remote, does not mean impossible. If the risk of censorship is unknown, then USDC is an existential threat to not only Maker but DeFi as a whole. IMO, convenience or the quest to capture institutional dollars, is not a good reason to abandon the ideals many of us actually believe in in DeFi: creating alternative financial ecosystems that are truly unique and with limited ties to TradFi. (We’ve already seen the terrible consequences of CeFi’s engagement with the crypto ecosystem.)   I don’t believe there’s a model to quantify this risk. I do not agree that USDC as an existential threat to DeFi as whole though, quite the contrary. USDC has enabled DeFi to grow and reach its potential and we have all the intention to see that continuing to be the case.     davoice321:  What legally/procedurally prevents Circle from being compelled to blacklist smart contracts such as Aave, Maker, Curve, etc. which have large amounts of USDC within them at the behest of a government agency due to, for example, concerns terrorists are using these platforms or they allow sanctioned individuals to transact without scrutiny?   First on principles. There are two primary drivers for access denial (the more “correct” term for blacklisting): complying with OFAC sanctions and abiding to court orders. Sanctions compliance is driven by observing the blockchain addresses added to OFAC lists (these are public). These addresses are usually associated with individual or commercial entities, not with an entire financial institution. In other words, it’s very unlikely to target an entire financial institution. If OFAC was ever to add some DeFi protocol address to a sanctions list, this wouldn’t be so much of a USDC-related problem, this would be an existential problem for that protocol in terms of how it touches any other regulated exchanges, wallets, on-ramps, etc. kinds of products. I don’t like to speculate, but that seems highly unlikely to me. On the court order side of things, that is a very high procedural bar and one where there’s an ability to object just as part of any legal process. I would call particular attention to this piece of the Centre Access Denial policy:  To the extent an order requires access denial of an address with commingled funds of a platform (or similar) and Centre reasonably determines that such access denial presents a threat to USDC, Centre reserves all rights to object to the order in the course of its participation in the proceeding.  The reason that was added to the policy is precisely because wrongly utilizing the access denial mechanism towards a commingled structure like a DeFi protocol or a centralized exchange represents a threat to the very existence of USDC. As you can imagine, we aren’t interested in destroying USDC’s reputation and future potential ourselves. We have the right to object these situations where it’s appropriate.     davoice321:  How is USDC’s business model (providing large-scale access to US dollars) in a way that is permisionless and without KYC, congruent with attempts to obtain a banking license, and become more compliant with existing regulations/policies and recommendations related to this issue.   I do not see the incongruence you seem to suggest here. Circle already is compliant with existing regulations in this space, and we already partner with the best US domiciled banks for a product like USDC. The amount of diligence required in this space wouldn’t allow these entities to work with us if they weren’t comfortable with the existing construct. I will not speculate on how regulations could sway in the future - I honestly think nobody can.     davoice321:  How does the ideal of decentralized finance, which fosters the free flow of financial assets globally without restriction align with allowing highly centralized organizations such as Circle (and its asset USDC) to have such a large influence on DeFi, given the centralization and censorship concerns associated with USDC?   Our mission is very much aligned with the ideals of decentralized finance. We also believe in things like consumer protection, fighting financial crime, maintaining a safe environment for all ecosystem participants. I would like to believe those things are not in opposition. We strongly believe there is a role for an asset like USDC - with a sound reserve model, trusted and regulated construct, and highly liquid profile, to benefit decentralized finance. As I said previously, the growth of DeFi on Ethereum and other ecosystems has proven for that to be the case. But the ecosystem needs to define for itself what other constructs have to be in place. We’ve always collaborated well with Maker and other participants who ambition to build a more decentralized model. We don’t see those as in opposition necessarily.     davoice321:  Finally, and I’m curious as to your take on this, what is the benefit of utilizing assets such as DAI, FRAX, etc. that are largely backed by USDC (or products, such as liquidity pools containing USDC, in the case of FRAX), versus simply using USDC? Aren’t these products largely redundant given their large-scale reliance on USDC?   I don’t believe they are redundant products. Assets like DAI, FRAX, etc. can typically innovate at a much faster pace when compared to USDC. They can iterate on UX and experiment with more flexibility. Sometimes I think about them as the “fintech” equivalent of tradfi. USDC can play a role in their growth and sustainability, and if they prove their concepts they should not have to depend on something like USDC. As always - and I’m sure as many in the ecosystem can attest to, we maintain an open mind and are happy to collaborate in a trusted manner with projects that are truly valuable like the ones mentioned here. Thanks for having me.

Folks since I consider myself the progenitor of the PSMs with the original idea (because I used to ‘arb the PEG quite a bit’), I think some comments are appropriate. My own goal was to simply use Maker’s ability to mint DAI (i.e. provide liquidity) and the relatively stable value of USDC (or other stables) to provide some liquidity to manage the DAI price.   My own vision for DAI PEG price management was to use multiple PSMs with increasing DCs and widening price bands. Example 50M for a band of like 5bps, 500M for a band of like 25bps, 5B at 50bps etc.    The point here was for Maker itself to do what I was doing with my vault.  Sell DAI high and buy it back lower and I wanted Maker to be the DAI liquidity source because it could offer MORE liquidity than a vault could all the time. @rune ran with this idea, he realized the SAI to DAI bridge smart contracts could be used, but he wanted 0 fees and effectively infinite liquidity on the high side, where as the liquidity of stables on the low side would be limited by the amount of stables.    This creates a perfect DAI short situation in that DAI price can never exceed 1 (unless the DC is hit or the ES is triggered) and if stables exhaust (and this can happen in a single tx btw) then the DAI peg can and will drop below $1.  This is all fine and dandy until the PSMs exhaust and the DAI peg drops below $1. The arguments for this were that it would increase DAI adoption as the DAI price away from $1 hurt adopters and would help IV vaults (as well as real world) by providing them a way to convert large amounts of DAI to USD via USDC etc. The reason the DAI PEG was riding high (like 1.02 consistently) was due to Compound adding COMP rewards for depositors and borrowers creating an incentive for recursive mining effectively changing borrow rates on DAI to below 0, and deposit rates above the SF fee on Maker.   Maker vaults just couldn’t supply the liquidity to keep the price below 1.02 and reducing fees pretty much did nothing.  I suggested we try to raise rates to make borrowing DAI more expensive but was overruled by the community (we never tried this even as a short term test). It took at least 6 months before @rune finally got his way and tin/tou was set to 0 and Maker never created multiple PSMs with multiple DCs and fee bands to create this liquidity provider of last resort on DAI goal to basically bracket the DAI PEG on the high and low side to no more than .5% which I would have considered very good for a decentralized stable.   Maker would also have earned profit doing this and it is likely we would not have 3.5B USDC in the protocol like today and even if we did - we’d have earned something like 10-30M doing it which would have grew the surplus to help us in many ways. What is worse here is that USDP and GUSD were added and all of these have tin/tout set to 0.  Maker in effect has force locked the prices of DAI, USDC, USDP, and GUSD to $1 with the PSMs.  IF any of these have any problems Maker will end up being on the hook for any liabilities caused by any of these dropping off $1 for any reason.   Most have considered such events unlikely but when someone tends to lock market prices to $1, eliminate friction via fees, at some point there almost always is an issue that leads to losses and intense regulator scrutiny.   Time will tell. Lately there has been discussion about adding fees again.     Rethinking PSM-fees Proposal Ideas   TL;DR I have been in favor of 0-PSM-fees to provide a hardened peg since the introduction of the PSM. I am now convinced that this was a mistake as this policy removes the incentive for normal vault holders to arbitrage on depegging and by that just leaving the leverage-usecase for vault holders. As the appetite for leveraging crypto is not very strong, we have reached a stablecoin ratio of ~80% recently - turning DAI more and more into a USDC-wrapper.   Rethinking PSM-fees For those not having…     As I argued in the past tin/tout to 0 basically kills exchange markets elsewhere.  Example uniswap .01 and .05 via GUNI would earn more fees if the current PSM was opened up.  Wouldn’t it be better for Maker to open up a trading gap so GUNI holders potentially earn more return encouraging more liquidity.    My goals are always to test solutions that encourage decentralized players to come forward with liquidity rather than the reverse and Maker hasn’t even moved to do a basic test of a change (by putting tin/tout to 5bps)  to see how the Uniswap .01, .05 v3 earnings and liquidity would change in response (same with curve btw) and whether this would finally allow for USDC to start migrating away from the PSM. This is my biggest beef with Maker btw in that it never does even a test change in system parameters to gauge market response.
